Problem 3.1

Making Smaller Ballots: Introducing Exponential Decay

In Problem 1.1, we read about the ballots Chen is making. Chen cuts a sheet of paper in half. He stacks the two pieces and cuts them in half. Chen then stacks the resulting four pieces and cuts them in half, and so on. We investigated the pattern in the number of ballots each cut made. In this Problem, we will look at the pattern in the areas of the ballots.

The paper Chen starts with has an area of 64 square inches. He uses a table to see if he can find a pattern between the number of cuts and the area of each ballot.

He wants to find a growth pattern that will help him predict the size of the area of a ballot after any number of cuts.
Is this possible? Explain. For example, without cutting the ballots, what is the area of the ballot after 10 cuts? After n cuts?
